WRITING.TEXT: I think it'll be an excellent card in the matchup, but it won't exactly win on its own.
Source?

It seems good, but not on its own. 3 damage won't kill Nissa or Gideon, so you need another creature swinging. It's less helpful late game because Sylvan Advocate, but it's tricky early game to have a creature to swing with AND delirium.

1. Declaration is much better as far as creature removal goes. I'd still keep Firecraft, since you're running Goblin Dark Dwellers, but drop it to 1-2 copies.
2. Thought-Knot seer! It's an incredible card, a 4/4 for 4 that also exiles their best card.

I'm on mobile so I can't do a full write-up, but here are a few notes:
1. You aren't doing Nahiri because of budget, but the rest of the deck is pretty expensive. If you can afford Nahiri she's really incredible in this deck.
2. Cut Sin Prodder. It's nowhere near as good as it looks. The extra card never goes in your hand, and the damage it deals isn't worth the lack of impact on the board state.
3. Wasteland Strangler is a great card if you have any exile removal. Speaking of which, Declaration in Stone should be a 4-of.
4. Drana is a good card, but it doesn't really feel at home here.
This could help make [[Thing in the Ice]] shells viable. Ability to throw down Thing turn 3 and still have mana to counter removal is not insignificant.
Oh boy, more great bant cards. Yay...

I think that's an overly optimistic assessment. Thalia is good, and it'll be a huge help for White humans in the matchup, but it's not going to single-handedly force Tokens to do anything more than add more removal, which White is still king of. As for Decimator, I'm very uncertain about how impactful it's going to be.
It'll be excellent in the mirror. And unless B/R/U get some serious boosts, GW Tokens is going to continue to be THE deck in Standard. I'd say it's a sideboard card for the mirror.

WRITING.TITLE: [Standard] Mono-White Archive
WRITING.TEXT:
http://tappedout.net/mtg-decks/standard-white-archive/
I'm trying to improve this deck, and I would love some criticism/advice from more experienced deckbuilders.
The heart of the deck is [[Alhammarret's Archive]], which doubles lifegain and card draw. This turns mediocre cards like [[Healing Hands]] into incredible value.
The deck is mono-white to maximize the value from [[Prism Ring]], which gives some massive lifegain over the course of the game.
I'm not really sure about a win condition yet. I'm currently mainboarding 4 [[Sunscorch Regent]] as the win con, but I've also experimented with [[Myth Realized]] and [[Linvala, the Preserver]].
My removal comes in the form of [[Declaration in Stone]] and [[Stasis Snare]], with [[Planar Outburst]] as a sweeper.
Other builds I've considered are:
1. A more creature-based version, including playsets of [[Cleric of the Forward Order]], [[Bygone Bishop]] and [[Serene Steward]].
2. A [[Felidar Sovereign]] shell, with [[Center Soul]] to keep it safe from removal.
3. A [[Myth Realized]] shell, with minimal creatures and much more removal.
I'd appreciate any advice that you could offer! I'm very excited about this brew and I think it's shaping up to be a fun, FNM-competitive deck.

See, this is a major part of the problem: nobody cares who their MEP is. This applies everywhere in Europe, not just Britain. Nigel Farage, who opposed the entire concept of the EU, managed to gain and keep the position of MEP with minimal effort.
And so he argues, not unjustly, that the European Parliament is undemocratic because only a minuscule portion of the European population actually votes in the elections.
Doubt it's Standard playable, but it'll be very welcome for Zombie EDH players.

This is a vastly superior version of General Tazri, and it's not even legendary. I'm not optimistic about the color balance in this set. It seems like either White gets several OP cards (i.e. color imbalance) or every color gets several OP cards (i.e. general power creep).
Let's not forget the Lifelink part. That's a hell of a clock for 4 mana.

It feels GREAT when you can ult Nahiri with 2 Stranglers in the graveyard, which makes the play:
Nahiri Ult-Swift Warkite-Wasteland Strangler from the graveyard--3/-3 a creature- swing with Warkite and Strangler- pass turn, Warkite and Strangler go into hand- cast Warkite- bring ANOTHER Strangler from the graveyard- -3/-3 a creature- swing with Strangler-pass turn, Strangler returns to hand
After 2 turns, you get a 4/4 Flier, 2 Strangler ETB effects and 2 copies of Strangler from your graveyard to your hand.
It's not competitively optimal, sure, but it feelsgoodman.
Obviously [[Linvala, the Preserver]]. But a favorite of mine for Mardu Nahiri is [[Swift Warkite]]. It allows you to bring back a [[Wasteland Strangler]] from the graveyard and use its ETB effect.

Looking for a tier-1 (or borderline tier-2) deck that is NOT White Humans. My budget is about $50. I'm tinkering with a budget UG Tentacles decklist, as well as the UR Fliers list. I really like everything, but my favorite archetype is probably aggro-control. What competitive decks fit that best?
This card could make Kiora actually playable in standard.
White Humans. It's cheap, it's simple, it's competitive. You can get creative, there are several different ways to build it, but it ends up being a very good deck to get into the format with.

The evidence presented at the Grand Jury clearly showed support for Wilson's story, in which he responded reasonably to at least the threat of violence. The opposing story had numerous flaws, was impossible on several different counts, and ultimately contradicted itself to be considered anything more than a pack of flat out lies.
Periodic table, because of freshman chemistry. No, I'm not kidding.

Furthermore, when tyshawn shoots dequan, tyshawn goes to jail while black victims of police violence struggle to have their case go to trial
Part of the argument is that Tyshawn often *doesn't* go to jail, because majority-black areas are systematically underpoliced. Dangerous criminals roam free in low-income, majority-black areas because police are too afraid to venture near them.
And it's precisely because of the racial backlash that officers get when policing black-majority neighborhoods. Remember Darren Wilson's shooting of Michael Brown? That was, in hindsight, entirely justified on Wilson's part. Unavoidably so. And yet Wilson "resigned" (no severance pay) and will never be a police officer again, because of the response by black-power movements.
*This* is what people mean when they talk about black-on-black crime being a bigger problem than police violence. A paranoia of police officers perpetuated by black-power movements is making it harder and harder for the law to keep order in black neighborhoods. And that's allowing dangerous career criminals to terrorize these communities. Children in these areas are brought up seeing nothing but crime, knowing no life but that of gangs and ghettos.

This is good stuff!
I had a budget Mardu control deck that looked a lot like this. The Nahiri-Fetch-finisher was Swift Warkite, which felt real good with a Strangler or two in the yard.
(Fetch Warkite-Warkite etb bring back Strangler-Strangler etb to kill an enemy creature-both return to hand-cast Warkite again-Warkite etb to bring another Strangler. End result: Two Strangler ETB effects, one 4/4 flier, and two more Stranglers in the hand. Feelsgoodman)
I was also using Topplegeist, since Delirium is pretty easy with the +2 and you don't have to spend mana like for Displacer. And I'm strongly of the opinion that Hallowed Moonlight should be MB for this meta, since it exiles creatures from Company AND can be used to delay token-producers for a turn.
In addition, I really dig the Oath of Chandra-Angelic Purge interaction for this deck. Sacrificing an Enchantment helps delirium, and exiling their cards helps Strangler. Plus, if not for the sacrificial "downside" Angelic Purge would be insanely good removal.
Just played against myself on tappedout against a few popular decks. I understand that it's not the best way to test accurately, so I'm wondering what the metagame consensus is for the deck,

I've tried building a Memories Milldeck too. I'd recommend including white for [[Bygone Bishop]], [[Bound by Moonsilver]] and [[Angelic Purge]]. Note, Memories triggers whenever you sac a clue for*any* reason. That makes Purge and Moonsilver premium removal that also help you mill.
Also consider [[Forgotten Creation]]. It makes the Tutelage clock extremely fast, and it can lock in a pinch.
What do you think about running 1-2 [[Embermaw Helion]]? It doubles your cluegrid damage and gives you a trample body for [[Confront the Unknown]].

The easiest and most budget tier 1 deck is white humans. But you can get a good tier 2 deck for around 20-30 bucks, easy. I'd recommend looking at UW Spirits as a cheap jumping off point. You can build a playable one for like $20, then just start playing. The more you play, the better you know both your deck and the others in the format.

It's a tough call. I've never been really good at perfecting the sideboard but I'd consider putting the negates in there for walker matchups.
That said, if you flip Thing then you have nothing between 7 damage and their planeswalker. Plus, Stormchaser is a fast flying bruiser in here, and there aren't too many good flying/reach creatures in the meta right now.
I swap negate. It's less effective at disruption, but against control it does a great job speeding up the clock and protecting your TitI, since it's two spells for one card and protects for 2 turns.
Have you considered [[Center Soul]], in either side or main? It casts 2 spells for 1 card, and protects TitI. I've been running it in Jeskai Visions and it's had good results.

I'm glad you're feeling better! Take this opportunity of energy and enthusiasm to take care of yourself. Make an appointment with a therapist. If you have bipolar depression it can be hard to think about the bad times during the good, but this is a great chance for you to set yourself on the path to recovery.

The "European Colonization of Americas" statistic is pure propoganda. I'm sorry, but there's no other way to put it. The total population of the pre-Colombian Americas is highly disputed, and it would take a very high estimate and a very negative view of colonization to reach 138 million.
In addition, characterizing the series of events as a "war" is enormously dangerous. It implicitly splits these events into a conflict with 2 sides, European and Native American. Never mind that the European powers were fighting each other most of the time. This strikes me as dangerously tribalistic and unrealistic, viewing history through a lens of "conflict between ethnic groups" rather than the more reasonable "conflict between states."
me too thanks

I feel like there is no "myself." I've been acting for so long I don't think there's anything genuine left, just a hollow shell that's good at pretending to be a person.

Honestly who gives a shit? There are so few "trans" people that we can judge whether they're mentally ill, physically uncomfortable or just special snowflakes on a case-by-case basis.

Of course self mill has its uses, I'm not denying that it would be an advantage in a well-built deck. But if you're going through 3 cards a turn instead of 1, just surviving ~18 turns becomes a win condition for your opponent.
And that's assuming you only use the +1 once. Use it twice and you've got guaranteed Delirium, [[Graveblade Marauder]] swinging for 10-20, massive [[Diregraf Colossus]] and other good combos. But if your opponent can stall you out, then you rapidly approach the bottom of your deck.

A planeswalker whose +1 gives you a detrimental emblem. I thought of this for a new Tibalt and it's an interesting design space. For example,
+1: you get an emblem with "at the beginning of your upkeep, put the top two cards of your library into your graveyard

Magic Trick
1UBR
Reveal the top card of your library, then shuffle your library. At the beginning of the next end step, reveal the top card of your library. If it is the same as the first card, take an extra turn after this one. Exile Magic Trick.

Frankly, one of the most underrated benefits of Brain is that it gets around tricky mana costs. Tragic Arrogance, for example, costs WW3, which might be hard to get unless you're running white heavily. With Brain, you can resolve it without a single white mana source in your deck.
I haven't tested yet, but I'm working on a 4-color Brain deck, topping out at Part the Waterveil and Seasons Past. I think it's promising, so maybe tinker around with other colors for a bit.
